propositions.text: A Trent University graduate student conducted a study comparing the net carbon emissions of the same building using different materials in each modeled scenario
propositions.sourceText: A Trent University graduate student’s study compared the net carbon emissions of the same building using different materials in each modeled scenario. The results were drastically different depending on the products used:

closest_embeddings.text: A Trent University graduate student’s study found drastically different net carbon emissions for the same building depending on the materials used in each modeled scenario

In a Trent University graduate student's study comparing building materials, a scenario utilizing wood framing, drywall, mineral wool, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in net carbon emissions that were 144 tonnes lower than a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab

In a Trent University graduate student’s study, a scenario using trusses and asphalt shingles, drywall and mineral wool, wood framing and drywall, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in lower net carbon emissions compared to a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab

propositions.text: In a Trent University graduate student's study comparing building materials, a scenario utilizing wood framing, drywall, mineral wool, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in net carbon emissions that were 144 tonnes lower than a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab
propositions.sourceText:
|Scenario|Materials Used|Net Carbon Emissions|
|---|---|---|
|Highest Emission|Clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, high embodied carbon concrete for the slab.|High|
|Lower Emission|Trusses and asphalt shingles|Lowered by 144 tonnes|

propositions.text: A Trent University graduate student’s study found drastically different net carbon emissions for the same building depending on the materials used in each modeled scenario
propositions.sourceText: A Trent University graduate student’s study compared the net carbon emissions of the same building using different materials in each modeled scenario. The results were drastically different depending on the products used:

closest_embeddings.text: A Trent University graduate student conducted a study comparing the net carbon emissions of the same building using different materials in each modeled scenario

In a Trent University graduate student's study comparing building materials, a scenario utilizing wood framing, drywall, mineral wool, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in net carbon emissions that were 144 tonnes lower than a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab

In a Trent University graduate student’s study, a scenario using trusses and asphalt shingles, drywall and mineral wool, wood framing and drywall, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in lower net carbon emissions compared to a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab

propositions.text: In a Trent University graduate student’s study, a scenario using trusses and asphalt shingles, drywall and mineral wool, wood framing and drywall, fiber cement for cladding, and average concrete with mineral wool for the slab resulted in lower net carbon emissions compared to a scenario using clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, and high embodied carbon concrete for the slab
propositions.sourceText:
|Scenario|Materials Used|Net Carbon Emissions|
|---|---|---|
|Highest Emission|Clay tiles, steel joists, high-VOC carpets, steel framing, cement brick for cladding, high embodied carbon concrete for the slab.|High|
|Lower Emission|Trusses and asphalt shingles|Lowered by 144 tonnes|
